Let T\TT be the unit circle in the complex plane C\CC and for each α∈T\alpha \in \Tα∈T define the rotation map Rα ⁣:T→T\func{R_\alpha}{\T}{\T}Rα​:T→T by Rα(z)=αzR_\alpha\p{z} = \alpha zRα​(z)=αz. A Borel probability measure μ\muμ on T\TT is called α\alphaα-invariant if μ(Rα(E))=μ(E)\mu\p{R_\alpha\p{E}} = \mu\p{E}μ(Rα​(E))=μ(E) for all Borel sets E⊆TE \subseteq \TE⊆T.

  1. Let mmm be Lebesgue measure on T\TT (defined, for instance, by identifying T\TT with [0,1)\pco{0, 1}[0,1) through the exponential function). Show that for every α∈T\alpha \in \Tα∈T, MMM is α\alphaα-invariant.
  2. Prove that if α\alphaα is not a root of unity, then the set of powers {αn∣n∈Z}\set{\alpha^n \mid n \in \Z}{αn∣n∈Z} is dense in T\TT.
  3. Prove that, if we fix a single α∈T\alpha \in \Tα∈T which is not a root of unity, then mmm is the only α\alphaα-invariant Borel probability measure on T\TT.
Solution.

  1. Given a Borel set EEE, we have

    m(Rα(E))=∫01χRα(E)(e2πix) dx=∫01χE(e2πi(x−α)) dx=m(E),m\p{R_\alpha\p{E}} = \int_0^1 \chi_{R_\alpha\p{E}}\p{e^{2\pi ix}} \,\diff{x} = \int_0^1 \chi_E\p{e^{2\pi i\p{x-\alpha}}} \,\diff{x} = m\p{E},m(Rα​(E))=∫01​χRα​(E)​(e2πix)dx=∫01​χE​(e2πi(x−α))dx=m(E),

    since the Lebesgue measure is translation invariant and e2πixe^{2\pi ix}e2πix is 111-periodic.

  2. If α\alphaα is not a root of unity, then α\alphaα must be irrational. Indeed, if this were not the case, then α=ab\alpha = \frac{a}{b}α=ba​ for some integers a,ba, ba,b, so

    (e2πiα)b=(e2πia/b)b=e2πia=1,\p{e^{2\pi i\alpha}}^b = \p{e^{2\pi ia/b}}^b = e^{2\pi ia} = 1,(e2πiα)b=(e2πia/b)b=e2πia=1,

    i.e., α\alphaα is a root of unity. Since α\alphaα is irrational, it follows that {αn∣n∈Z}\set{\alpha^n \mid n \in \Z}{αn∣n∈Z} are all distinct. Otherwise, if αn=αm\alpha^n = \alpha^mαn=αm, then

    e2πinα=e2πimα  ⟹  e2πi(n−m)α=1  ⟹  (e2πiα)n−m=1,e^{2\pi in\alpha} = e^{2\pi im\alpha} \implies e^{2\pi i\p{n-m}\alpha} = 1 \implies \p{e^{2\pi i\alpha}}^{n-m} = 1,e2πinα=e2πimα⟹e2πi(n−m)α=1⟹(e2πiα)n−m=1,

    i.e., α\alphaα would be a root of unity. Hence, the powers of α\alphaα are all distinct, so they form an infinite subset of the compact space T\TT. Thus, they must accumulate, so for any ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, there exist n,m∈Zn, m \in \Zn,m∈Z so that

    ∣e2πi(n−m)α−1∣=∣e2πinα−e2πimα∣≤ε.\abs{e^{2\pi i\p{n-m}\alpha} - 1} = \abs{e^{2\pi in\alpha} - e^{2\pi im\alpha}} \leq \epsilon.∣∣​e2πi(n−m)α−1∣∣​=∣∣​e2πinα−e2πimα∣∣​≤ε.

    Thus,

    T=⋃k=1∞B((e2πi(n−m)α)k,ε),\T = \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty B\p{\p{e^{2\pi i\p{n-m}\alpha}}^k, \epsilon},T=k=1⋃∞​B((e2πi(n−m)α)k,ε),

    so the powers of α\alphaα are dense.

  3. Let μ\muμ be a Borel probability measure which is α\alphaα-invariant on T\TT. We will show that μ\muμ is rotation invariant: let β∈T\beta \in \Tβ∈T and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. By density, there exists {αnk}k\set{\alpha^{n_k}}_k{αnk​}k​ so that αnk→β\alpha^{n_k} \to \betaαnk​→β in T\TT. Then

    μ(E)=μ(Rαnk(E))=∫01χRαnk(E)(e2πiθ) dμ(θ)=∫01χE(e2πi(θ−nkα)) dμ(θ).\mu\p{E} = \mu\p{R_{\alpha^{n_k}}\p{E}} = \int_0^1 \chi_{R_{\alpha^{n_k}}\p{E}}\p{e^{2\pi i\theta}} \,\diff\mu\p{\theta} = \int_0^1 \chi_E\p{e^{2\pi i\p{\theta-n_k\alpha}}} \,\diff\mu\p{\theta}.μ(E)=μ(Rαnk​​(E))=∫01​χRαnk​​(E)​(e2πiθ)dμ(θ)=∫01​χE​(e2πi(θ−nk​α))dμ(θ).

    Since μ\muμ is a probability measure, the integrand is bounded by 111, which is L1(μ)L^1\p{\mu}L1(μ), so by dominated convergence,

    μ(E)=lim⁡n→∞∫01χE(e2πi(θ−nkα)) dμ(θ)=∫01χE(e2πi(θ−β)) dμ(θ)=μ(Rβ(E)),\mu\p{E} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_0^1 \chi_E\p{e^{2\pi i\p{\theta-n_k\alpha}}} \,\diff\mu\p{\theta} = \int_0^1 \chi_E\p{e^{2\pi i\p{\theta-\beta}}} \,\diff\mu\p{\theta} = \mu\p{R_\beta\p{E}},μ(E)=n→∞lim​∫01​χE​(e2πi(θ−nk​α))dμ(θ)=∫01​χE​(e2πi(θ−β))dμ(θ)=μ(Rβ​(E)),

    so μ\muμ is rotation-invariant. Now, observe that

    1=μ(T)=∑k=0n−1μ([kn,k+1n])=nμ([kn,k+1n])  ⟹  μ([kn,k+1n])=1n=m([kn,k+1n])\begin{gathered} 1 = \mu\p{\T} = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \mu\p{\br{\frac{k}{n}, \frac{k+1}{n}}} = n\mu\p{\br{\frac{k}{n}, \frac{k+1}{n}}} \\ \implies \mu\p{\br{\frac{k}{n}, \frac{k+1}{n}}} = \frac{1}{n} = m\p{\br{\frac{k}{n}, \frac{k+1}{n}}} \end{gathered}1=μ(T)=k=0∑n−1​μ([nk​,nk+1​])=nμ([nk​,nk+1​])⟹μ([nk​,nk+1​])=n1​=m([nk​,nk+1​])​

    for any k=0,…,n−1k = 0, \ldots, n-1k=0,…,n−1, so μ\muμ agrees with mmm on rational intervals, hence on any interval, by dominated convergence. Thus, because intervals generate the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra, it follows that μ=m\mu = mμ=m, which was what we wanted to show.
